Fields.DialogueText: Thank you for waiting for me to finish paying my respects, Kanchou. I presume this is about boiler number 4?
The boiler is what brought me looking for you, Kongou, but the incense is what led me here.
I hope you don't mind.
When we kept the Emperor's portrait in the officer's wardroom I was curious who would pay respects to him given our rather eclectic commissioned team.
It is true not all my officers are Japanese now.
With your background and style...
You presumed I'd abandon my traditions?

Fields.MenuText: Not at all, Kongou. I had just been curious how you would respond to the changes.
I'll admit the thought had occurred to me. You weren't born Japanese, after all.
You were essentially bought by the Japanese. I thought perhaps you might want to exercise your freedom now.

Fields.DialogueText: Both the British and Japanese appreciate the value of tradition.
Quite true, Kanchou. I was born in England.
I am exercising my freedom.
If it helps, think of me as a woman in an arranged marriage. To become Japanese was decided for me before I was born.
All the more reason...
For me to reject my family?
Do not misunderstand me. I am proud of my British roots, but the Combined Fleet and the entire nation of Japan welcomed me with open arms.
You are certainly popular on the home front.
They honored me by entrusting the Crown Prince himself to me on one of his longest journeys.
Really?
Hai. True, I had no choice in the matter of my adoption, but one can't choose their birth parents either. I am British by birth, and hold England dear.
But...
But I am Japanese. And remember, Kanchou. I am your ship by choice. I will never leave your side.
Thank you for your trust in me, Kongou.
We have a Funayūrei lurking to port. Before we fight her, I'd like to make a request.
Of course, Kongou.
Although I will serve you to the end, Kanchou, my duty to the Emperor is also important to me. I wish to do my Combined Fleet sisters proud. If I should fall...
... will you please ensure this portrait is kept safe? It is my solemn final duty to see that the Emperor's likeness is not claimed by the sea.
@BATTLE
If that day comes, but it won't be today.
Mode im Bild? I didn't know you read German, Kongou.
I don't, Kanchou. I can speak it enough to converse with the German officers on board, but not enough to navigate a fashion magazine.
Did you by chance enlist Korvettenkapitän Merkel to help you with your fashion questions?
That's exactly whom I've been speaking with. He comes from a tailor's family and has a wealth of knowledge about German fashion.
This explains what my executive officer was talking about.
Oh?
Kongou, Mr. Merkel has duties, and I need him focused on them. Translating German fashion magazines isn't really our core mission.
He has the time.
That isn't exactly true. I need him working a new assignment regarding Morgana research we were handed from Command.
That's silly. All he does in his free time is work on those carvings of his. What a waste of his talents working with wood... when he could be working with fabric!
I'm doing him a favor, Kanchou.

Fields.MenuText: Have you asked Mr. Merkel what he thinks about that?
Kongou, just because he comes from a family of tailors doesn't mean he likes working with clothes.
That's a pretty presumptive thing to say, Kongou.

Fields.DialogueText: Ask him? But isn't it obvious he'd be drawn to his origins? Fabric is in his blood.
It doesn't? But aren't those his origins? He must love fabric.
It is? But he comes from a family of tailors. Wouldn't that mean he'd love working with fabric?
Hmm. I think we're touching on a difference in perspective. Humans don't always follow in our parents' footsteps.
They don't?
No, they don't. Mr. Merkel may be drawn to carving exactly because he doesn't want to work with fabric but still wants to work with his hands.
Perhaps that's why Mr. Peltier has been so resistant about talking with me about Parisian designs.
Mr. Peltier? The flight officer? Just how many of my crew have you been hijacking for your hobby?
Hijacking is such a strong word. And fashion is never a hobby, Kanchou. It is core to what makes us civilized. How can we expect to act professionally if we do not look it?
And speaking of uncivilized appearances. The Funayūrei flaunt their hideously clashing color choices nearby. They must be taught the error of their ways.
@BATTLE
I hope your dinner was enjoyable.
It was lovely, Kanchou.
I sense a "but" coming up, Kongou...
Perhaps. I know you've instructed your chef to ensure my meals are the highest quality Japanese fare...
He hasn't met your expectations?
Oh, no! Give my compliments to the chef. He's truly captured the essence of ootoro and I've never had miso so divine. And the tea is most excellent.
But...
A western dish now and then wouldn't hurt.
Western? As in British?
Indeed. Fried fish, for example? Or bully beef and eggs.

Fields.MenuText: Heh, so you do miss England sometimes.
But... didn't you say you consider yourself Japanese?
Bully beef? I'm not familiar with the dish.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't get me wrong, I love Japanese cuisine. But occasionally I crave something... meatier?
I do, Kanchou. Absolutely. Still, I hope I can be forgiven desiring an occasional taste of the West.
Ah, it's an English term, Kanchou. Salted beef finely minced and packed tightly in a tin. I suppose it could be considered an acquired taste.
I think I understand. I'll pass that along to the galley staff and see what they come up with.
That would be lovely. Have them include a good plonk... Wine, I mean, too. But before such talk, we have Funayūrei wishing to stand between us and the mochi.
How rude.
Isn't it just?
@BATTLE
Well, Kongou, another parade inspection went as well as can be expected. What a challenge, inspecting officer uniforms from a dozen countries.
It was certainly... eclectic...
That's a good word for it.
I think a better word would be appalling.
I guess I can't argue. It's bad enough on the parade deck, but it makes a mess of things in day-to-day operations.
A Soviet officer not knowing how a Kaigun-Daii relates to a Korvettenkapitän, for example. And everyone not native to this ship is mystified by the Japanese crew ratings.
I'm still spending an inordinate amount of time translating authority between the crew and the officers.
You've gone above and beyond the call of duty, Kongou. We'd never manage this without you.
It shouldn't be this difficult, though. Uniforms are critical to maintaining discipline and a unified sense of purpose on a ship. Uniforms are meant to be... Uniform!
How much longer will Command drag their feet before sending us Protection Fleet uniforms?!
They're still saying within the month.
And they'll probably still be saying that three months from now.
Kongou, I know you're used to special treatment in the Combined Fleet. But there are glaciers that move faster than most military bureaucracies.
Have you at least been able to find out who's producing them? I'd love to at least know which designer is working on it.
From what I hear, the contract went to someone in Buenos Aires.
Buenos Aires? As in Argentina? South America?
So I'm told.
But what of Paris? London?
My guess would be the Argentinians were the lowest bidder.
Lowest bidder!?

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry. I know you don't like hearing that, Kongou.
Hey, don't shoot the messenger.
May as well get used to it, Kongou.

Fields.DialogueText: Our crew's clothing shouldn't be up for bid!
Then whom shall I shoot, Kanchou?
Keep in mind there are land wars going on. Anyway, shouldn't we first wait to see what these people produce? You might like it...
It is fortunate the Funayūrei present themselves when I need a punching bag.
@BATTLE
So, Kongou, is this what you had in mind?
Very much so. I'll admit, I'd have never expected tinned beef sauteed in sherry and served with a horseradish garnish, but I'm pleasantly surprised.
It is delicious, I agree.
The garnish reminds me of wasabi.
So, when you eat Japanese you think of Western... and when you eat Western you think of Japanese?
When I eat good food, it reminds me of good food.

Fields.MenuText: In some ways, I'm jealous. You get the best of both worlds.
It seems to have prepared you well to help coordinate an international crew.
It must have been hard for you to adapt at first.

Fields.DialogueText: That's a good way of looking at it. My Japanese sisters have accepted my... eccentricities... and it's certainly prepared me for my role in the Protection Fleet.
It has, Kanchou. Very much so. I enjoy having both Western and Japanese crew members and helping them find common ground.
My sisters made be feel at home. Whatever challenges may have been presented, the current events make it all worth it. I feel well prepared to help unify an international crew.
I really don't know how I would have managed this crew without you, Kongou.
You know, Kanchou, when I said "plonk," I meant you didn't have to find an extravagant wine. Still, this vintage is delicious.
It was suggested by the XO. It's from his home country, and he's quite proud of it. He says the vineyard is on the coast, and when he fights Morganas, he imagines he's defending it.
He should be proud. I can think of worse things to fight for.
Hear, hear.
And fortunately for him, if not for us and this meal, Funayūrei skulking near the coast right now must be persuaded back to the open ocean.
@BATTLE
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
Now can you see why I was concerned!
They are... creative...
Creative? They're hideous! Just to start, green is NOT a naval color.
The tag claims it's khaki.
That is the greenest khaki I've ever seen! And the fabric doesn't breathe. It gets hot in my machinery spaces even when it's temperate on deck. The crew will be stifled!
A point made when the contract was put to bid, I believe.
So how did this happen?
Not everyone in positions of power like the extra-nationality concept. There are those who would prefer to see the whole Protection Fleet fail.
So it's a conspiracy?
I wouldn't go that far, but maybe it wouldn't hurt to dig a bit. Lowest bid contracts tend to turn out... inventive. Let me see what I can find out.
I will reach out to my contacts, too.
You have contacts?
Of course! I haven't been the star of the Combined Fleet for over a quarter century without making a few friends.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose that makes sense. Just don't get in over your head, okay?
We're at sea, Kongou. How will you contact these friends?
I expect you to let me know before you commit us to anything.

Fields.DialogueText: You can trust me, Kanchou.
Oh, a lady has her ways.
Of course, Kanchou. I'll be sure to keep you updated.
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
It's unacceptable, Kanchou! Simply unacceptable!
I'll admit it doesn't look terribly durable...
It's not just that. It's garish! What is Command thinking?

Fields.MenuText: Kongou, it's just paint. They've already stripped the hull. You have to wear something.
I have a feeling that you won't be satisfied by my pointing out that it's just paint? You have to wear something over your steel, right?
Garish or not, it's the paint we've been supplied, Kongou. You can't go parading about the seas in naked steel you know.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not a child, Kanchou. Don't treat me like one.
Kanchou, if it's as durable as it is sensible I won't have it on my hull for long.
What makes you think I won't try?
At least it's not a full camouflage scheme. And you know as well as I do that paint protects your hull and keeps you from rusting. It isn't just aesthetics, Kongou.
Maybe for a non-Belle ship. I could stave off hull oxidation.
And tend to all your duties? Staving off rust wouldn't distract you at all?
Kongou, I'll add this to my protests about the supply chain. I understand that we're not the only ones complaining. It just takes time.
It had better not take much more time. And if so much as a drop of that swill stains my teak deck, there will be hell to pay.
It looks like I might have the chance to discuss our logistics issues with some big wigs.
That's good news!
First I want your promise that you'll leave the politics to me, okay?
I mean it, Kongou. Believe it or not, things could get worse.
As you wish, Kanchou.
We're carrying some VIPs to the next League of Nations working conference.
A diplomatic mission?
Yes, Kongou. A Navy Minister, Navy Chief of Staff, and their respective staffs.
Sounds like important people. The kind that walk around with targets painted on their backs.
Exactly. It's too much ocean to risk flying over with the Morganas so active in these waters. Anything less than a battleship seemed risky, but speed was of the essence.
So, of course they thought of me.

Fields.MenuText: That isn't a question, is it?
That's a bit conceited. There are other battlecruisers in the fleet.
Well, there's no one else better suited for it.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course it isn't, Kanchou. There's no better ship in the fleet for such a mission. I'm proud to accept.
Perhaps, Kanchou. But none as fast and experienced carrying VIPs as I. Why, I've carried the Crown Prince!
I'm glad you understand.
Just remember, if we encounter Morganas along the way, we're not supposed to engage. Our duty is to get these brass from point A to point B without rattling them too much, okay?
They'll barely know they're at sea, Kanchou. Just make sure that I don't regret getting them there.
@BATTLE
I thought I'd find you here.
How many drinks does this make? Two?
Three... I think. Maybe four? Yes, this is number four.
I think...
Is it helping?
I should have been there.
You can't be everywhere, Kongou.
Why not?
You should be proud of her. She managed to fight off a Morgana light cruiser. Not bad for a regular ship without a Belle.
At what cost, though?
Rumor is there's a high priority new build in Nagasaki. Something big. She did what needed to be done to protect her infant sister.
She's always been stubborn. Why she hasn't manifested...
Maybe this will give her the incentive to do so. Damn if I know what causes you ladies to come out, but Japan will fix her up good as new.
What's left of her...
I'll agree she was lucky to be so near the Mitsubishi shipyard... lucky for her and the shipyard. The seas were calm. Still, as you said, she's stubborn. She did survive.
Of course she did! We Japanese battleships are made of stern stuff.

Fields.MenuText: Exactly! Your sister proved that to everyone.
You certainly hold your own.
I suppose, but it helps when they have a Belle.

Fields.DialogueText: Damn right she did! Just wait until the Emperor hears about this.
She sure did that, Kanchou.
Perhaps. But did you read that report? Even without a Belle, my sisters can do the Emperor proud.
You certainly do him credit.
I'll do him more credit and work out my frustrations right now, Kanchou. There's a Funayūrei peeking over the horizon at us.
You sure you're up to it after four drinks?
My current state is ready and able to fight, as always. A little grape juice won't stop me from my duty. Call the crew to action stations!
I have a lesson to teach the Funayūrei. Do not mess with the Combined Fleet, bitches!
Far be it from me to tell you your business, but you're weaving out of your lane. Here, hold my arm.
@BATTLE
Kanchou, Malice is in firing range!
Lieutenant, why is that loaded floatplane still on my deck?
The catapult's still jammed, Kanchou! The charge misfire totally warped the rail. We can't get it to budge!
Kongou?
I could fling it away if it were detached...
The pinion is still bent. The crew would throw the damned thing overboard themselves if that wasn't the case, but it's stuck tight. The crews are trying to cut it loose as we speak.
How did Malice sneak up like that?
She came out of the shadow of the island at full speed. I had no chance to react before she was on us. It's like she knew we were there...
A submarine?
Most likely. It would make... Incoming!
@BATTLE
Damage report!
We're starting to get a handle on the fires with Kongou's help now that she's not focused on the gunners.
And other than the fires from the floatplane wreckage?
Moderate damage reported elsewhere... except engineering's still a mess from the aft end near miss.
Lieutenant, there's probably a sub out there. What's our best speed?
We're down to 12 knots max per the engineer.
That's not fast enough to outrun Asphyxiation or her sisters. Kanchou, permission to help engineering free the #3 shaft. It's fouling both starboard screws.

Fields.MenuText: Permission granted. The sub threat is our biggest worry right now and speed our biggest asset. The fire crews will have to fend for themselves for a bit.
Permission denied. I need you back on those fires. We've lost enough men to that damned fueled floatplane. We need to prevent more casualties.
Permission denied. I need you keeping a lookout for that submarine. Speed and doused fires won't mean a thing if something sneaks up on us again.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Kanchou. I want away from here as fast as possible. Still...
As you wish. Just make sure everyone not fighting the fires with me or helping free that turbine are watching for torpedo tracks. Also...
If you insist. I'll join the lookout crews. Still...
We will talk later. Suffice it for now that tonight I'm taking every one of those damned new uniforms and throwing them off the stern!
Kanchou, what do those nitwits in the League think they're doing sending us uniforms that burn like they've been oiled! You may as well have just soaked the crew in kerosene!
They say the idea was to add water resistance. Help the crew stay dry in foul weather. It was actually part of the bid.
They went up like candle wicks! Have you been to sickbay?
You know I have, Kongou.
It's bad enough that so much of me burns so well. I don't need the men keeping me from becoming torches themselves!

Fields.MenuText: I don't think the uniform contractor thought it through.
I saw what you saw, Kongou, and I'm just as angry as you.
Kongou, calm down. You're getting hysterical.

Fields.DialogueText: Damn right they didn't think it through! Lowest bidder...
Are you? How can you stomach this lowest bidder rubbish?
I'm not hysterical, I'm furious! How many more good people do I lose to the lowest bidder?
You'd be at the mercy of the lowest bidder even if the Morganas hadn't shown up.
Kongou, even the Japanese bid contracts.
But lowest bidder doesn't have to mean lowest quality and thoughtlessness. Where's the oversight? Someone would have been shot by now if I were still with the Combined Fleet!
I can't argue that. Still, hopefully something will come of the conference. For now, we collect the new uniforms and return to status quo.
For now.
@BATTLE
You still deny there's a conspiracy?
How many died on Admiral Graf Spee-san? How many will live disfigured for the rest of their lives?
The final toll looks to be eighteen dead. Another thirteen or so will likely never return to duty.
Is there anyone with half a brain who would use oil-based paints on a warship! How could this not be a plot?
The contract...
Let me guess, the lowest bidder?
The Polish company had never had a naval contract before.
The bureaucrats at the League are still inexperienced with military matters. It didn't occur to them to make sure the paint... or the uniforms... wouldn't burn.
As we suspected. They're incompetent.
We?
The Kami of the Fleet. Even before what happened to Graf Spee-san, we started talking about our experiences.
You can do that?
We can. Piggybacking coded messages with radio traffic that only we recognize.
And?
Over half of the ships who have received the new uniforms have discovered the flammability issue. We've put out the word to discontinue their use.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you for doing that. We need to prevent any more needless loss of life.
I'm sure I'll be hearing about this from my peers.
I'd have appreciated it if we'd let that filter through official channels.

Fields.DialogueText: I had hoped you'd understand. We can talk more as we learn more.
That's not all you'll be hearing, I suspect.
I understand your respect for the chain of command, Kanchou. Usually I'd agree. If you have more to say on the matter, I'll gladly listen.
But first we have Funayūrei to contend with.
@BATTLE
What happened on the Admiral Graf Spee hit the news in the democracies. It's not exactly pretty. It's blown up into a major international incident.
Oh?
Germany's accusing the League of reckless disregard of its "loaned assets." Given the war, it doesn't help that the paint contractor was Polish.
League HQ is scrambling to respond, scraping the flammable paint out of the handful of Belles who had received it.
Hmm. This may work to our benefit, then.
Benefit?
I've been assigned to design a new uniform for the fleet. Only manufacturers with extensive experience making naval uniforms shall be permitted to bid for the contract.
Assigned? I haven't received such orders.
We Belles have recognized that the supply chain directly impacts us. We've learned that the "lowest bidder" is a worse enemy than the Funayūrei!
The Belles?
I've convinced my peers that we must become more involved in such matters. Make our voices heard.

Fields.MenuText: I hope you know what you're doing, Kongou.
You've convinced?
This sounds an awful lot like collectivization.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course I do, Kanchou.
I am well respected by my peers, Kanchou.
The Soviet ships suggested exactly that. Leningrad and Mahan are leading an exploratory committee on the idea. So far the conversation has been... lively.
Captain, to the bridge. High priority message from HQ awaiting your response.
I have a bad feeling about this...
It will have to wait until after we deal with Funayūrei forces, Kanchou.
For once I'm actually glad for the interruption.
@BATTLE
I can't let you have Mr. Merkel, Kongou.
But Kanchou...
I know you have approval for the uniform project. I'll help however I can...
And Mr. Peltier?
You can have the flight officer. Just don't interfere with his fighting duties.
I wouldn't dream of that. I'm a fighting ship after all!

Fields.MenuText: The best in the fleet, right?
I'm glad you're not forgetting that.
With your little rebellion, I was beginning to wonder about that.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course! Now, let's see to that Funayūrei patrol.
Not only am I not forgetting, but another opportunity to prove my prowess is here.
Rebellion? You use such strong words, Kanchou. I am your ship, and will follow you to the end.
@BATTLE
... but Command has placed a higher priority on the data gathering they want our comms crew working on.
Wield me to victory against the Funayūrei on the horizon!
Kongou, we need to talk.
Kongou, don't ignore me.
Kongou, can you please explain why you took control of a six inch turret...
... while docked...
... to blow up a pier?
They annoyed me, Kanchou.
Who annoyed you? Kongou, opening fire in port is serious. Even if no one was located where you lobbed 40 kilograms of high explosives, others might think it's an attack.
If you hadn't noticed, there are human wars going on too. People are understandably anxious.
Of course I know that, Kanchou. My Combined Fleet sisters are fighting for Japan off China, after all.
So why...
It's the sea lions, Kanchou. Swimming around where I can't see them. Slapping my hull. They cut through the water like...
Ah, I think I understand now. They remind me you of torpedoes.
I... just don't like them. They were a nuisance. Now they're serving a purpose.
Did you know that blubber is used to make cosmetics?

Fields.MenuText: It all comes down to appearances for you, doesn't it Kongou? Still, there are more appropriate ways to support the cosmetics industry.
It is? Maybe that's why the bill for pier repair seemed strangely small. Still, there are better ways to handle sea lions.
Kongou, you're changing the subject.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps. But none were available at the time.
True. I had considered torpedo netting, but apparently none is available for the Protection Force.
Not really, Kanchou. What could be more important that maintaining civilian morale? Women everywhere will thank my contribution to the war effort.
And in any case, I have no regrets.
It was very satisfying.
Am I going to have to secure your guns while in port?
That would be unwise, Kanchou. Who knows when a Funayūrei might lurch towards a port?
Such as right now.
Once again, convenient timing for you.
@BATTLE
Let us meet in battle, and come out victorious.
@BATTLE
How goes the uniform redesign?
Abysmally. It's even worse than I feared!
It's that bad?
It's that bad. The Soviet Belles rejected the fleet uniform before the flammability problem even came up, on the grounds of poor design.
Poor design?
They've informed me that unless they get to keep their telnyashkas they'll keep rejecting it, too. Something about not being able to say 'we wear telnyashkas' if they aren't.
It's just a striped shirt under a tunic. That doesn't sound unreasonable. What's the catch?
The French Belles are sticklers on the design: 21 white stripes.
That's rather specific.
It's the number of times Napoleon beat the British. ... Or so they claim.
And the list goes on and on.

Fields.MenuText: Naval uniforms are similar for the most part, so I guess the devil would be in the details.
Face it, Kongou; no one is going to be completely satisfied by a fleet-spanning design. The best you can hope for is everyone annoyed, but no one annoyed to the point of rejecting it.
Have you thought of making changes over time? Several small steps could get you to the same endpoint as a huge leap.

Fields.DialogueText: If only the answer was as simple as bringing in an exorcist.
It's that kind of attitude that leads to half-hearted attempts and lackluster results. I refuse to give up before I've even tried.
The supply chain takes too long as it is. No, it's better to pull the dressing off quickly and get the pain over with.
Good luck.
Kongou, can you explain the meaning of these orders?
Let me see. As of... transfer of... to... yes, this will do.
But these are orders to transfer both of your stewards to another ship. Did they do something to upset you?
Not at all.
Then why the exile? And so close to the arctic circle...
This isn't exile for them; it's field testing. Remember when I asked for missions as far north as we could manage?
I do remember that. You also wanted any missions near the equator.
Hai. And I still say I could have handled that last mission...
That was on the other side of the globe...
And with my speed, I'd have been there with time to spare.

Fields.MenuText: You're in high demand as it is. We can't have all the fun.
You could've been there on time, but it meant missing our resupply rendezvous.
You're good, Kongou... but not that good.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose you have a point.
Again with the supply line!
Nonsense! Where there is a will, there is a way, and my will is absolute.
In any case, as much as I'd love to compare the prototype uniforms against current issue, it's been made abundantly clear that I won't get as many chances as I want.
So, I'm sending my stewards out to the extremes, starting with winter and rough seas. I trust them to put the prototypes through their paces and give me details when they return.
That's actually not a bad idea. It means other crews will be seeing your prototypes though. Are you prepared for their feedback this soon?
Of course. It took longer than I thought, but my designs are flawless.
If anything, this will increase fleet-wide morale when people see how fashionable and functional the new uniforms will be.
I hope so. Still, remind me to see they get a merit bonus for all this. Even if you're right, that kind of testing is still a thankless job.
@BATTLE
Scientists.
That's what the orders here say. A Japanese-German consortium representing several electronics manufacturers.
Lowest bidders?
In this case, it doesn't look like it. This project seems to have caught the eye of the national governments. No expense spared.
No expense, hmm? Lucky them.
So, what could be so important about some scientists that they'd open their purses like that? Not to mention interrupt my patrol to meet with a float plane to take them aboard?
They're here to gather data. Up until now, they've been working with Mr. Merkel but they're at a point where they want to do the work themselves.
This is what deprived me of my best German fashion resource?
Something about better ways to track Morganas through their mists, particularly for mundane ships without Belles.
Hmmm...
I think they want to help regular ships make up for not having that sixth sense of yours. To prevent what happened off Nagasaki, or at least give them a fighting chance.
What can it hurt?
You ask me when they offloaded boxes marked with Swastikas? You know how I feel about Nazis.
None of the scientists appear particularly zealous, Kongou. They all seemed professional enough.
They're installing equipment on me and it feels... odd.

Fields.MenuText: That's a problem. I don't want them messing with you. I'll make them to stop.
They didn't waste any time, did they? Is it a problem? If it's hurting you, I'll ask them to stop.
I'm sure they know what they're doing, Kongou.

Fields.DialogueText: No, it's okay. It doesn't hurt. And I want to help if it can improve my unmanifested sisters. It just feels strange. Like I'm seeing sounds. I'm not sure how to interpret it.
It's not that it hurts. And I do want to help if it can improve my unmanifested sisters. It just feels strange. Like I'm seeing sounds. I'm not sure how to interpret it.
I hope so, Kanchou. It's not like I don't want to help my unmanifested sisters. It just feels strange. Like I'm seeing sounds. I'm not sure how to interpret it.
Perhaps we should go talk with them. When I gave the green light for their work, I didn't expect it to have an effect on you that pronounced.
It will have to wait. We have Funayūrei who must have been attracted by the Kawanishi. The HG6K is awfully big...
Can you signal the pilot to get airborne ASAP, Kongou? I'll meet you in the bridge.
@BATTLE
Everyone! To your stations!
@BATTLE
See?
I told you the sea lions were an omen!

Fields.MenuText: Perhaps, but omen or not we survived.
Kongou, you know as well as I do that the sea lions in port had nothing to do with this.
Has it occurred to you that rendering them to blubber might have caused them to haunt you?

Fields.DialogueText: Due to luck more than anything. I'm starting to think the fleet needs to assign a destroyer to me.
Can you be so sure, Kanchou? Before the Funayūrei appeared, the idea of a fleet of ships with Kami would have been in the realm of fairy tales. Yet here we are.
Hmmm... I hadn't thought of that. Perhaps I should erect a shrine to them.
Anyway, did the scientists gather anything from this one? There was no mist.
They're saying they noted some "interesting data points", but that the results are "inconclusive".
They sure like that word. They've used it every time we meet the Morganas.
Science takes time, I suppose. That's what they keep telling me anyway.
Still, if we're going to empower non-Belle ships the way we want, they're going to have to eventually conclude something.
So you'd think...
Kanchou, they keep asking for something with a more powerful mist. "The bigger the better." It might be dangerous, but shall we go hunting a Funayūrei battleship ourselves?
You really want to help your non-Belle sisters, don't you?
Of course I do, although I wouldn't mind new tools myself either. Still, I get the sense these white coats have more on their minds than they're saying.
Keep your ears open. In the meantime, let's go hunting.
She's out there.
Sedition?
Finally.
She's led us on a merry chase, hasn't she?
Not anymore. Are the scientists ready?
They say they are.
The equipment seems to be working, for all I can tell. Shall we engage her?
We're as ready as we'll ever be...
@BATTLE
We managed to give as good as we got, there. Kongou?
I suppose...
Something the matter? The damage reports seem pretty mild for a one-on-one with a Morgana battlewagon.
The scientists are arguing over the data. They're not sure what to make of it.
Don't tell me... "Inconclusive"?
That word is being bandied about. The consensus is that they'll need some time in the lab and come back with a new prototype.

Fields.MenuText: That sounds hopeful.
More time? How much more time?
Have I told you how much I appreciate you Belles appearing fully formed? If we'd had to depend on the scientists in this fight, we humans would have been driven to the mountaintops by now.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope so...
They aren't sure.
The thought had occurred to me...
I saw the latest orders. It looks like your stewards will be rejoining us at our next port.
Hai.
You don't sound very happy.
I'm not. Not at them, mind you, but...
Bad news travels that fast?
Unfortunately. Thanks to the other Kami of the Fleet, brief reports from them have been getting to me regularly.
So what did they learn?
Various things. Places that needed extra stitches... the number of layers that kept them warm and still had full range of movement...
The summer set was durable enough, but the cloth was still too heavy to breathe properly.
But that doesn't surprise you.
No. Those are the usual problem areas. I had hopes... but that's an issue I had anticipated.
You found something you overlooked?
Not really overlooked... but the rank issue hasn't been officially addressed yet.
That is a problem.
Yes. For example, the German Kriegsmarine has an entire parallel enlisted rank structure for those who are career versus minimum service. Not every country in the fleet has that.
That's a good point.
Where do British Warrant Officers fit since they don't hold the King's Commission?
Hmm...
Add to that the American Navy's myriad enlisted ratings, my homeland fleet's color coding by department... and don't get me started on the Soviets with their party department...

Fields.MenuText: That's not including awards and medals either.
Not that I don't sympathize, but isn't it always something else?
That's probably where you should have started in the first place.

Fields.DialogueText: No. It is rank and insignia that make each navy stand apart, at a time when they should stand together.
Uniforms, rank and insignia all go hand in hand. These are major issues, and until they are resolved will only continue to pull energy away from lesser but equally important ones.
Can I help it if I had that particular issue better under control than other Belles?
Besides, separate styles for officer and enlisted is the first and fastest means to establish pecking order.
I can see that.
It's hard to design a system for recognizing ranks when the ranking system itself is still fluid.
On that... It may be easier for you Belles to communicate, but you aren't the only ones who are putting your heads together on this one.
It's cobbled together and unofficial, but there is a shorthand system gaining traction. Any insight from your field testers?
Not much. Not until I can debrief them face-to-face anyway.
@BATTLE
Experimental shells?
Sanshikidan incendiaries, to be exact. Japan's finest. Rubber thermite fragmentation for area effect. This particular batch is designed for ground bombardment.
Ground bombardment? But the Funayūrei have no territory.
An enterprising Combined Fleet ordnance officer thought to offer the prototype Type 3 batch to you to see how they work against the Morganas directly.
I see...
You Belles make any round pack more punch. The Byzantines used Greek Fire a thousand years ago. The Combined Fleet thought "Belle Fire" was worth a try.
"Belle Fire"? I like that phrase.
I thought you would. So, do you think your new toys will be effective against the Morganas?
I think that I will love to see them burn...
@BATTLE
Inconclusive? But we had them on the run!
That's the problem. Our targets ducked into the mist before any data could be collected.
They weren't happy, I can tell you that!
But that doesn't tell us anything about the effects of the Sanshikidan over the standard high-explosive shells. They said it warrants more study, but...
... But I don't get any more of those rounds.
This was an experiment with prototypes. The production rounds are going to the war effort against China, it appears.
And the League? Would they buy a production batch for the Protection Fleet?

Fields.MenuText: They'd want to put it to bid.
Would the Japanese sell them? They were particular that the prototypes would go only to you and that only the Japanese crew handled them.
I don't think the League could afford them..

Fields.DialogueText: Please, not that!
You do have a point. If there is one thing the Combined Fleet cherishes, it's their secrets...
Maybe the Turkish proposal to turn to piracy wasn't such a bad idea after all...
Everyone! To your stations!
@BATTLE
I swear, the next person who utters the word "inconclusive" on this ship will be fired from the number one turret!
I understand your disappointment...
We risked the whole crew for these battles, and the results after all that work were "inconclusive"?!
You yourself said that science takes time.
They had plenty of time. My sisters are fighting out there. Helpless! I thought for sure we'd get a new tool from all this running around.
Instead, it's "inconclusive."
What a waste of an unlimited budget.

Fields.MenuText: I can sympathize with your feelings, Kongou.
Not every bet pans out, Kongou.
Ah ha, we get to the heart of the matter. You're jealous.

Fields.DialogueText: While I am sincerely appreciative that we can hold common ground, sympathy is not a solution.
We gamble with something far more precious than chips or coins, Kanchou.
I envy the resources that could be put to better use in a war, Kanchou. To prevent bitter loss of life.
I know, Kongou. I feel every loss as much as you do. Still, you're used to military independence from government. Things are different now that we're under the League.
It's more like what you were born to. I'd think you could appreciate the potential positives of civilian control of the military.
Civilian control? It was only a few years after I was born that civilian control earned the British Empire their defeat at Gallipoli.
Forgive me my desire to rather emulate Admiral Tōgō at Tsushima.
Fair enough.
Kanchou! We need to make a course change. That alert about the major Funayūrei activity in the area? I've found them!
And you have your uniform proposal meeting. Being late to that would affect your submission, without a doubt.
Agreed. Though it may sound ridiculous to some, that meeting is a high priority.
We could send the word out, shadow them and leave for your presentation as soon as there are other Belles to hand off the chase.
Although, if you think there's enough time though, we could throttle them here and now.
As Ambassador to the Fleet, I'm well aware that punctuality is a virtue...
... but, I also believe you should never put off an attack on the Funayūrei for tomorrow that you can do today. We have plenty of time.
@BATTLE
... And now we wait.
And now we wait.
Kongou...
Arrggghh! What is taking so long!?
Patience, Kongou.
... Is a virtue, my Kanchou. But even I'll admit that it isn't one of my stronger ones.

Fields.MenuText: You did well, Kongou. This is nothing out of the ordinary.
It could be worse, right?
I hadn't noticed.

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose you're right. It doesn't make the waiting for the results any easier though.
It should be a more decisive answer than that.
I meant to save it until there was a verdict, but maybe a trip to the galley would help take your mind off the wait.
You don't mean...
How does bangers and mash sound?
Bangers... bangers? Oh, yes... Bulldog mentioned something about sausages and mash having a new nickname...
Your composure has been impeccable.
Arigatō. I am no stranger to diplomacy. Yelling at them wouldn't have opened their empty heads. That said, those nitwits couldn't get off my deck fast enough for my taste.
What did they even mean, "inconclusive"?!
I suppose in this case, it means they aren't fully convinced what you came up with would meet all the needs of everyone.
But...
And be produced to a certain level of quality fast enough and in sufficient quantities.
But...
And stay within budget.

Fields.MenuText: It was a valiant effort.
You aren't the first to receive a vague, unsatisfying answer from higher-ups, and you won't be the last.
You didn't lose for lack of trying.

Fields.DialogueText: Valiant or not, I'm back to square one; a crew without cohesive dress who need a codebook to decipher each other's ranks and ratings.
I suppose I should be used to vague answers by now.
I didn't lose. I merely failed to impress them.
Look on the bright side. Your stewards were transferred to Fleet Command to help research the issue. You practically trained them for this.
Thanks to you, at least two of the next designers will know what to plan for.
Hm... There is that.
Leave it in their capable hands. In the meantime, a mission came up that I think you'll find interesting.
Oh?
You remember the attack on Nagasaki? Based on accounts from the ship crew and shore staff, the Morgana was identified as Avarice.
Avarice!
According to the pickets, she was spotted ten hours ago. I hear Morgana light cruisers are in season...
You have our hunting license? When do we leave?
Right away! Onward!

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad Kongou's on my side. She's great!
She really is something...
